Dear Mr. Skornia:
First off, I want to tell you the Fact Sheet Service is a reliable
source of information which we find very helpful. Thank you for it.
In reference to paragraph two of Fact Sheet Series IV, Number 7,
December 1, 1955, under production procedures, I would like to say,
that we have used radio and television in simulcasts for a television
series, involving a panel of two experts and a moderator, dealing with
two books which treated the same or similar subject matter. Listeners
were as much impressed as viewers but for different reasons and in
varying intensity. No formal research was made on this program.
Another incidence in which our radio station was used to augment our
television productions, occurred in the telecast credit course series
of basic Literature and Fine Arts-music, last spring. One-half hour
before the program was telecast, music of the period was presented by
radio as a required segment of the telecourse credit program. This
made possible the inclusion of many musical selections illustrative of
the period to be discussed in the lesson. Students felt it provided
great enrichment for the course. Direct line from the television studio
to the radio station was used for the simulcast. Continuity linked the
radio series and augmented the music telecast.
The simulcast was carried in the fall term of 1954, the music course
was telecast spring term, 1954. In our present schedule of planning,
both programs will be reissued in 1957.
You indicated in the Fact Sheet that you would like to have suggestions
or comments concerning this correlation of radio and television so we
were prompted to send the information along to you.
Very sincerely yours,
Television Producer-Coordinator
